titleStmt.title: S.W. Hall v. William Billings. Writ

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: S.W. Hall v. William Billings. Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: Territory of Washington, Second Judicial District, Ss.
Before Roger S. Greene Associate Justice of the Supreme Court At Chambers Eighth January, A.D. 1879
In the matter of the Petition of S. W. Hall for a Writ of Habeas Corpus

Territory of Washington County of Cowlitz, Ss. Daniel Delaney, being first duly sworn deposes and says, I know George H. Holliday; I knew him since the fall of 1859 at Carlin- ville, Macoupin County, Illinois; I was person- ally acquainted with him; he was a friend of mine; he was the person that gave me my naturalization papers; I was person- ally acquainted with him until the fall of 1870 or the spring of 1871; he was a man of high standing in our county, busi- ness transactions called me sometimes to see him; at the time he gave me my naturalization papers he was county clerk, and the Probate Court was in session - it was in the fall of 1859; I lived in Girard, a small town north of Carlinville and was in the trolley business, and Mr. Holli- day would frequently come over to the town and would call and see me as he would of his friends; I have seen him quite often, have ridden with him on the cars and have been as familiar with him as a man would want to be; have seen him frequently in his office in shirt sleeves; I am as satisfied that this prisoner is George Holliday as that I am Dan. Delaney; I know I cannot be mistaken.
Daniel Delaney sworn to and subscribed before me, this 8th day of January, A.D. 1879
Roger S. Greene, Assc. Justice of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory
Received from Judge R.S. Greene Filed January 17th 1879 R.G. O'Bruin Clerk
